title: 106_hr446
content: ELIMINATION OF TAX SUBSIDIES FOR ETHANOL FUEL. Elimination of Credit for Alcohol Used as Fuel in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including amendments to sections 40 and 38 for general business credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 eliminates the credit for alcohol used as fuel by amending sections 40 and 38 for the general business credit. Section 40, relating to alcohol used as fuel, is treated as referred to after subsection (b) and any other credits mentioned. The table of sections is updated by removing the item related to section 40, and section 87 in Part II of subchapter B is also eliminated. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 eliminates the credit for alcohol used as fuel by amending sections 40 and 38 for the general business credit. Section 87 is removed from Part II of subchapter B, along with other amendments to sections 56, 196, and 6501(m) of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 eliminates the credit for alcohol used as fuel by amending sections 40 and 38 for the general business credit. Section 87 is removed from Part II of subchapter B, along with other amendments to sections 56, 196, and 6501(m) of the Code. The reduction of other incentives for ethanol fuel includes the repeal of the reduced rate on ethanol fuel not produced from petroleum or natural gas. Subsection (b) of section 4041 is amended to exempt liquids sold for off-highway business use from tax. The text chunk discusses the definition of off-highway business use and the repeal of the reduced rate on ethanol fuel produced from natural gas in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change the tax rate on fuel alcohol and other motor fuels, specifically ethanol. Ethanol is no longer included in the definition of taxable fuel, and the tax rate for fuel alcohol is set at 2.15 cents per gallon. The tax rate on fuel alcohol, including ethanol and methanol, is amended in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The definition of fuel alcohol is clarified as alcohol produced from sources other than petroleum, natural gas, or coal, and withdrawn from the distillery tax-free for fuel use. The tax rate on fuel alcohol is amended in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Special rules for fuel alcohol production are outlined, including treating the distillery as a refinery and specifying minimum transfer quantities. Reduced rates on alcohol fuels are repealed. Repeal of reduced rates on alcohol fuels in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including amendments to sections 4041, 4081, and 4091. Conforming amendments to section 4041(a)(2) specify no tax on fuel alcohol if tax was imposed under section 4081. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding alcohol taxes. Section 6427 is amended by removing subsections (f) and (i)(3), as well as amending paragraph (2) of section 6427(k). Additionally, paragraph (1) of section 6427(l) is amended to include fuel alcohol on which tax has been imposed under sections 4041 or 4081. Amendments are made to section 6427 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding alcohol taxes. The amendments include exempting fuel alcohol from tax imposed under sections 4041 or 4081 and updating the heading of subsection (l) to include fuel alcohol. Sections 9503(b)(1)(D) and 9508(b)(2) are also amended to remove references to kerosene. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include adding fuel alcohol to the list of exempted items from tax, updating subsection headings, and renumbering paragraphs. Effective dates for these changes are specified. The enactment of this Act eliminates the section 40 credit for alcohol produced after the enactment date. A floor stocks tax of 18.4 cents per gallon is imposed on fuel alcohol held on the enactment date, with liability and payment methods specified by the Secretary. The tax imposed on fuel alcohol must be paid within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Definitions for "fuel alcohol," "held by a person," and "Secretary" are provided. There is an exception for exempt uses. Exception for exempt uses: The tax on fuel alcohol does not apply if held for specific uses where a credit or refund is allowable. No tax on fuel alcohol in vehicle tanks. No tax on fuel alcohol held by a person if the amount does not exceed 2,000 gallons on the date of the Act's enactment. The Secretary requires specific information for tax purposes. Fuel held by exempt persons is not considered. Controlled groups of corporations are treated as one person. The term "controlled group of corporations" is defined as having more than 50 percent control, similar principles apply to nonincorporated persons under common control. The term "controlled group of corporations" applies to entities with over 50% control, including non-corporate entities under common control. Other laws applicable to taxes under section 4081 also apply to floor stock taxes imposed in the same manner.
